She decided to invest them in a small store. Presently her small store has grown and now sells products that she didn’t before. She wakes up really early to open her store, and at the same time takes care of hers son and performs her domestic choose.

With this loan received of 1,300 Soles, which will be paid back in 4 months. She invested that money in buying groceries, like, sugar, salt, rice, milk, oil, noodles, jams, flour, eggs, soft drinks and etc.

Eloisa puts a lot of effort in making her small store grow, and she feels very happy about that. Her goal is for her store to grow more and to become an enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Johnny of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Eloisa pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Caribeñas, ubicado en el Jr. Río Pisqui 388, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 31 años es casada, tiene 1 hijo, su esposo es albañil. Eloisa con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertir en una pequeña bodega.

En la actualidad su bodega ha crecido ahora vende productos que antes no lo hacia. Se levanta muy temprano para abrir su bodega, y así mismo atender a su hijo y realizar los labores domésticos.

Con este préstamo recibido de S/. 1,300, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, lo invertira en la compra de abarrotes como: azúcar, sal, arroz, leche, aceite, fideos, conservas, harina, huevos, gaseosas, etc.

Eloisa puso mucho esfuerzo para que su bodega crezca, y se siente muy feliz por eso. Y su meta es que su negocio crezca hasta ser una empresa.

loans.use: buying products

loans.name: Lizbeth

texts.es:
Lizbeth is a member of the communal bank located in the district of Calleria. She is 33 years old, and happily married. She has one child.

She currently owns a restaurant, where she offers breakfast and lunch. She wakes up early to go to the marketplace and buys ingredients need to make food.

With her upcoming loan she hopes to buy bulks of: sugar, chicken, fish, meat, spices, vegetables, oils, tables, plates and utensils.

Lizbeth is a hardworking woman. She hopes to increase her sales and make her restaurant a great success.

Translated from Spanish by Edith of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Lizbeth pertenece al Banco Comunal Juntas Hasta el Final, ubicado en la Av. Alfonso Ugarte 683, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años es casada, tiene un hijo.

En la actualidad tiene un restaurante, donde ofrece desayunos y almuerzos, se levanta muy temprano para ir al mercado y comprar los víveres que necesitara para la preparación de sus comidas, con la ayuda de empleados realizan la preparación de las comidas, por las tardes descansa para la faena del día siguiente.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de: 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, pollo, pescado, carne de res, condimentos, verduras, aceite, mesas, platos, cubiertos.

Lizbeth es una mujer muy trabajadora y con las ganancias obtenidas agrandara su restaurante y también ofrecerá otros tipos de platos para todos los gustos.

loans.use: Products for making her restaurant's meals.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
Lidia is a member of the communal bank, located in Bella Vista in the district of Calleria. She is 43 years old. She has 4 children. With her first loan she decided to invest it in the sale of food.

She continues her business. She wakes up early to go to the marketplace and buy ingredients needed for the preparation of food. With help from her kids, they manage to make the food and sell it in the afternoon.

She hopes to get another loan, this time for 1,000 Soles, which she will repay in 5 months. She will buy a bulk of rice, sugar, chicken, fish, bananas, vegetables and other spices.

Lidia is a mother and father to her kids and she does it with a lot of effort to give them a great education and meet their needs.

Translated from Spanish by Edith of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Lidia pertenece al Banco Comunal Juntas Hasta el Final, ubicado en la Av. Bellavista 1101, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 años es separada, tiene 4 hijos. Ella con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida.

En la actualidad continua con este negocio, se levanta muy temprano para ir al mercado y comprar los víveres que necesitara para la preparación de sus comidas, con la ayuda de sus hijos realiza la preparación, y por las tardes realiza las ventas

Con este préstamo recibido de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de: 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, pollo, pescado, cecina, plátano, verduras, condimentos, etc.

Lidia es madre y padre para sus hijos y todo lo hace con mucho esfuerzo, para darles una buena educación y que no les falta nada,a sus hijos

loans.use: she will buy products for making her meals to sell

loans.name: Mayra

texts.es:
Mayra belongs to the community bank “Las Triunfadoras”, located at 374 Bellavista Ave., in the district of Calleria in the department of Ucayali. She is 43 years old and the mother of three children: her husband is a welder. With her first loan received from Manuela Ramos of 300 Soles she decided to invest in a welding workshop.

Currently, she sells food and continues with her welding workshop: with the help of her children she prepares the food whilst her husband looks after the workshop.

With this loan of 3000 Soles, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy materials for her workshop, tools and provisions for preparing her food dishes.

Mayra is very happy with the loans, as thanks to them she is managing to realize her ambitions and give her dear children the basic comforts in life.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Mayra pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Triunfadoras, ubicado en la Av. Bellavista 374, D. Distrito de Calleria D. Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 años,es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es soldador. Ella con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decide invertir en un taller de soldadura.

En la actualidad vende comida y continua con su taller de soldadura, con la ayuda de sus hijos prepara sus comidas, y su esposo se dedica a la atención de su taller de soldadura.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprara materiales para su taller, fierros, víveres para la preparación de sus comidas.

Mayra esta feliz con los prestamos, ya que gracias a ellos esta logrando sus metas que se trazo y puede dar comodidad económica a sus seres queridos.

loans.use: Purchase materials for her workshop

loans.name: Mariela

texts.es:
Mariela belongs to the Community Bank “Las Caribeñas”, located at 159 Jr.Fistarrald, in the district of Calleria in the department of Ucayali. She is 36 years old and is single. Mariela used the first loan of 300 Soles she received from Manuela Ramos to invest in the purchase and sale of beauty products.

Currently, she is continuing to sell beauty products and also spends time selling groceries and sweets which provide her with a good income: she alternates between these activities and her university studies and her work in a law center.

With this loan of 1300 Soles, which will be repaid in four months, she will invest in buying more beauty products, such as colognes, lipsticks, eye shadows, perfumes, and single and double bedspreads.

Mariela feels very happy working with the community bank because they are united in solidarity.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Mariela pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Caribeñas, ubicado en el Jr. Fistcarrald 159, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años es soltera. Mariela con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidide invertir en la compra y venta de productos de belleza.

En la actualidad continua con la venta de productos de belleza y también se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y golosinas que le dan buenos ingresos, y a la vez lo alterna con sus estudios universitarios y su trabajo en un consultorio jurídico.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, lo invertira en la compra de artículos de belleza como colonias, labiales, sombras, perfumes, juegos de cubrecamas de 2 plazas y 1 plaza.

Mariela se siente muy cómoda trabajando con su banco comunal por que son muy unidas y solidarias.

loans.use: Purchase products

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
Zoila belongs to the Community Bank “Las Triunfadoras”, located at block 8 Jr. Alfonso Ugarte in the district of Calleria in the Department of Ucayali. She is 33 years old and single. With the first loan of 300 soles she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in the sale of food.

Currently, she has a stall in the Bellavista market, getting up early to sell her juanes (rice-stuffed leaves) and tamales, and in the afternoons she buys the raw ingredients which she needs to prepare her dishes. She then goes to bed early to prepare for tomorrow’s work.

With this loan of 1300 Soles, which will be repaid in five months, she will invest in the purchase of rice, oil, condiments, eggs, meat, sugar, plantain, and regional fruits. Zoila feels very content with her business and with all her achievements.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Zoila pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Triunfadoras, ubicado en el Jr. Alfonso Ugarte Cdra. 8, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años es soltera. Ella con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida.

En la actualidad tiene un puesto en el mercado de Bellavista, se levanta muy temprano para ir a vender sus juanes, tamales, en las tardes compra sus insumos que necesitara para la preparación de sus comidas, y descansa temprano para la faena del día siguiente.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de: arroz, aceite, condimentos, huevos, carnes, azúcar, plátano, y fruta regionales. Zoila se siente muy bien con su negocio y con logros alcanzados

loans.use: Purchase provisions for the sale of her food products

loans.name: Monica Lisbeth

texts.es:
Mónica belongs to the Community Bank “Las Triunfadoras”, located at 651 Jr. Los Ceticos in the district of Manatay in the Department of Ucayali. She is 37 years old and the mother of three children. Her husband is a motortaxi driver. Monica invested the first loan of 300 Soles she received from Manuela Ramos in the purchase and sale of motor lubricants.

Currently she has a mechanic’s workshop and a spare-parts store in her house, she also owns a motortaxi for which she is still paying. In the mornings she busies herself caring for her children and with domestic chores, and in the afternoons she attends to her business.

With this loan of 1000 Soles, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy parts for the motortaxi, spare parts and clothes to sell.

Mónica is united with her companions at the bank because they are like a family for her.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Mónica pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Triunfadoras, ubicado en el Jr. Los Ceticos 651 del Distrito de Manatay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 37 años es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es motocarrista. Mónica con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertir en la compra y venta de lubricantes.

En la actualidad tiene un taller de mecánica y venta de repuestos en su casa, cuenta con un motocarro que esta pagando todavía , en las mañanas se dedica a atender a sus hijos y a las labores domesticas, y por las tardes atiende su negocio.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprara piezas para su motocarro, repuestos y ropas para vender.

Mónica es solidaria con sus compañeras de bancos por que son como una familia para ella.

loans.use: Purchase products for her business

loans.name: Juanita

texts.es:
Juanita L. is the mother of two teenagers, aged 16 and 14. For reasons of fate, she had to take responsibility for advancing her children’s lives. Looking for a means of doing this, she established her business three years ago selling jewellery among her friends and neighbours. Today she’s contemplating looking for a bigger market.

For this reason, she is asking for a loan of $475 USD which she will repay within 6 months. She needs this money to buy merchandise and to be able to offer her services to more people. Let us help Juanita in order that she can obtain a better income for her family.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Juanita L. es madre de familia de 2 adolescentes de 16 y 14 años por cuestiones del destino ella tuvo que sacar a sus hijos adelante, buscando la manera de hacerlo emprendió su negocio vendiendo joyería entre sus amigos y vecinos hace 3 años, hoy en día abarca un mayor mercado.

Por esta razón solicita un crédito de US $475 que pagara en 6 meses lo necesita para comprar mercancía y poder ofrecer sus servicios a mas gente. Apoyemos a Juanita para que obtenga mejores ingresos para su familia.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Luis Alfonso

texts.es:
Luis Alfonso T. is the proprietor of a convenience store: the history of his business began a year ago when he saw published in the paper an announcement publicizing the opportunity to operate a convenience store and he decided to do it in order to have a better source of income.

He needs a modest loan of $475 USD which will be repaid in five months in order to expand his business through purchasing more merchandise. Alfonso will be very grateful for your help.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Luis Alfonso T. es comisionista de una tienda de conveniencia, la historia de su negocio comenzó hace un año cuando vio publicado en el periódico un anuncio donde se ofrecía la oportunidad de tener una tienda de conveniencia y decidió hacerlo para tener una mejor fuente de ingresos.

El requiere de un apoyo económico de US $475 que pagara en 5 meses para hacer crecer su negocio comprando mercancía. Alfonso agradecerá tu ayuda.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Klut

texts.en: Mrs. Klut M., 50, is married with seven children and is sometimes hired by the Villagers as a farmhand making $1.50 a day.  Her husband, who is also farmer usually earnsaround $1 a day of profit. Two of their children are married and live separately from home. Moreover, three of their children work as garment workers in Phnom Penh city with a salary $70 to $80 every  month. This couple requests a loan from Kiva to purchase good rice seed and fertilizers to put on the farm. Any leftover will be used to renovate their house as now they face a difficulty with a leaking roof during the rainy season.

loans.use: To purchase good rice seed and fertilizers and to fix the leaking roof.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Mrs. Sem Y., 44, is a mother of six children and, with her husband, works as a farmer on a plot of  land earning around $1.50 a day. Two of their children are married and live away from home. Two other children work as garment workers and earn a salary of $80 a month. This couple requests a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for their two daughters who commute to work at a factory. They currently commute by  motor-taxi which is very expensive.  The purchase of the motorbikes  will reduce the commute expense and allow the family to save for the future. (Mrs. Sem Y. is not available for pictured, husband only)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng L., 58, is a widow with 5 children that stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for the famiL. members. She also owns a plot of farmland and grows a variety of vegetables and makes, on average, about $1.5 a day of profit. Her son, the oldest brother in the famiL., works as a construction worker. On average, he earns $15 a day. Her other four children are employed in the garment sector and each earn a salary of $70 to $80 a month. She requests this loan to make a well (deep well), grow grass (cow food) to sell and to purchase construction tools for her son to use at work.

loans.use: To dig a well, grow the grass and purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Bol

texts.en: Mrs. Bol C., 37, fishes for a living together with her husband. After catching fish, they sell their catch in the market and earn approximately $10 a day of revenue. They have four children, one of who is a garment worker that earns a daily profit of $2. The remaining children are students. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorbike to transfer the fish to sell in the market. (Picture: wife, husband and one of  their children).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transfer fish to sell in the market.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng Y., 51, grows rice and a variety of vegetables and earns about $1 a day of profit. Her husband stays at home and helps his wife with the farming. They have 5 children, one of who is married and lives away from home. Three others are employed by a garment factory and each earn a salary of $70 a month. The youngest child is a student. To reduce expenses, this couple requests a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for their children to commute to work. This will allow the family save for the future. (Picture: husband and wife,  the children behind are the neighbors kids).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for their children to commute to work.

loans.name: Thi Ngai

texts.vi:
Mrs Ngại is 43 years old. She has been selling basic goods to make a living for a long time now. She also raises pigs to increase her income. She has 3 children who are employed so they could help her with the living expenses. Mrs Ngại has never borrowed money before because she lives far from a bank. Now she has joined SEDA because the loan officers go down to her village to distribute the loan and pick up the payment as well. She has applied for 2006000 VND to buy pigs and basic to resell.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Ngại, 43 tuổi, làm nghề đi chợ sắt vụn từ lâu. Thêm vào đó, chị còn chăn nuôi lợn thịt để tăng thêm thu nhập. Chị có ba con giờ đều đã đi làm nên phần nào đỡ cho bố mẹ trong cuộc sống hàng ngày. Chị chưa từng vay vốn ở đâu vì sự bất tiện và xa xôi khi vay ở Ngân hàng. Nay, chị tham gia chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì ở đây cán bộ xuống tận nơi để thu và phát vốn. Chị đã vay 2006000 đồng để đi chợ sắt vụn và chăn nuôi.

loans.use: buy basic goods to resell, pigs

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs. Ros E., 51, is a widow and has a business selling banana ice cream (the ice cream is mixed with banana) in her community. She normally earns around $12 a day in revenue. She has five children, one of whom is married and lives away from home. Two of her children sell banana ice cream like their mother, earning about $6 a day in revenue. She requests a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike to transfer the ice cream to sell door to door (they now use a bicycle). People like banana ice cream in her village so this business is also lucrative.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to sell banana ice cream.

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny N., 29, is a mother of three children and works as a farmer. She earns around $3 a day of profit. Her husband is a rice dealer. He makes on average $5 a day. All their children are students. He wants to use this loan to purchase rice in bulk so that he can save money. A rice broker in Cambodia can make more profit as the price of rice is going up.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk to save the money.

loans.name: Heab

texts.en: Mrs. Heab K., 29, is a mother of three children that stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her family members. After the house work, she works as a tailor and normally earns around $4 a day. Her husband supports the family as a motor-taxi driver, making around $3.50 a day of profit. To increase their standard of living they request to loan from Kiva to purchase another motor-taxi for their son to run as a business.

loans.use: This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Peng

texts.en: Mrs. Peng P., 43, works as a tailor earning around $2 a day of profit. Her husband is a farmer and grows a variety of vegetables on a plot of farmland. On average, he can makes about $2 a day of profit. Sometimes he can makes more especially in raining season because he has enough water for his crops. This couple has eight children, five of who are tailors like their mother and the rest are students. To increase the output from his  farm they request a loan from Kiva  to purchase cow to plow the farm. Now he hires a tractor to plow the farm so it costs him a lot.

loans.use: This loan will used to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Njuk

texts.en: Mrs. Njuk M., 39, owns a plot of farmland with her husband and they grow vegetables. They make on average $8 a day of income. This couple has four children and all of them are students. They make a good profit from planting vegetables. To increase growing they are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase petroleum, fertilizers and seed (vegetables). (Husband is pictured because Mrs. Njuk M. is not available)

loans.use: To purchase petroleum, fertilizers and seed (vegetables).

loans.name: Kun

texts.en: Mrs. Kun Y., 62, is a mother of eight children and owns a plot of farmland where she grows vegetables. She normally sells the fruits and vegetables in the market. On average, she can earn around $3 a day of profit. At the same time, her husband works as construction worker building houses and earns around $5 a day. Three of their children are married and live away from home. Two daughters are employed by a garment factory and each earn a salary of  $80 a month. The remaining children stay at home to help with the house work. This family has difficulties with a leaking roof especially in rainy season which is why they are requesting a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: This loan will be used to fix a leaking roof.

loans.name: Prek Deaung Iii Group

texts.en: Mr.Meng T., 48, is a farmer and also the Village Bank President. He is married with eleven children: three aR. students; two aR. factory workers earning $60 each per month; the other six children aR. too young to attend school or to work. His wife, Bonthon Chhon, makes $2 per day, while he makes $5 per day. He would like to request the loan in order to buy moR. sugar cane to sell every day, as well as fertilizer and fuel.

loans.use: To buy more sugar cane to sell, fertilizer, and fuel.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim S., 40, is married with five children and, with her husband, sells corn. They normally earn around $5 a day of profit. One of their children is married and lives away from home. One son works as a goldsmith and makes $120 a month and another one is a tailor. The remaining two are students. They are now requesting a loan from Kiva to expand their business by purchasing more corn to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more corn to sell.

loans.name: Huk

texts.en: Mrs. Huk O., 43, sells rice (rice with variety of foods), eventually earns around $2 a day of profit. Her husband Mr. Kong Srang, 50, is a well maker (he digs to make  wells) in his village and makes on average $5 a day of profit. They have four children, one of who is married and lives away from home. The other children are students. To help his business grow, he needs to purchase tools (this equipment is use to dig the well). (A mother of Mrs. Huk O. is pictured because Mrs. Huk O. and her husband were not available).

loans.use: To purchase tools to be used to dig a well

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima N. is the group leader for four other women. Saima has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan, all of her life. Her husband operates a car rental, and she wants to improve and expand the business.

The other members of Saima's group are Shahida B., Shahnaz B., Suriya B. and Akhter-un-nisa B., all of whom are hardworking entrepreneurs who plan an important role earning income for their families. They operate various businesses including rickshaws, fruit sales and a restaurant.

loans.use: Expand car rental service

loans.name: Asiah's Group

texts.en:
Asiah A. is married and a mother of six: four girls and two boys. She lives with her family in a mud brick house in the small town Chichawatni, Pakistan. Her husband is a welder and has been in business for more than 17 years. She is requesting a loan to buy a welding plant for his business. If their income increases this year, she plans to buy a refrigerator for her house, so that her kids can drink cold water in the burning hot summer.

Asiah's group members are: Azra B., borrowing for her bakery; Razia B., to expand their fruits business; Naseem A., whose husband buys and sells vegetables; and Hameeda B., for their fruit trade.

loans.use: Buy a welding machine

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
I am Kalsoom Manzoora, a widow from the small town Chichawatni, Pakistan. I have seven kids: four boys and three girls. My elder sons are the bread winners of the family. One son does farming and raises vegetables. We need a loan to buy pesticides for his field.

My group includes: Shamshad B., whois borrowing to start a public call office; Suriya B., who wants to expand their grocery store; Rubi B., who will invest her share of loan in her family’s tailoring business; and Anwer B., who needs this loan to expand their general store.

loans.use: Buy pesticides for the farming land

loans.name: Muhtor

texts.ru:
Muhtor Hasanovich B. is 46 years old, married and has four children. He has been feeding and breeding cattle for the past 15 years. His children and wife Barchinoy have been helping him. Besides that he has a business of buying and selling oil and petroleum products from which he receives a steady income. Muhtor's wife works as a teacher in the Login village school. Her salary is 170 somoni (about US$50). They spend the income from the resale business and wife's salary on living expenses and save the income from the cattle business and invest it back into business expansion to increase the number of cattle.

Currently, Muhtor plans to buy fodder and three sheep for feeding and growing.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Vounteer.

Бердиев Мухтор Хасанович - 46 лет. Женат имеет 4 детей. Откормом скота занимается более 15 лет. В этом ему помогают дети и жена Барчиной. Кроме этого он занимается куплей продажей горюче смазочными материалами. От этого дела он получает стабильный доход. Жена Мухтора работает учительницей в средней школе села Логин. Получает заработную плату 170 сомони. Получаемый доход от торговли и заработную плату жены они тратят на жизнь , а доход от скота он вкладывает в текущий бизнес (увеличивает количество скота).

В данный момент он планирует закупить комбикорм и три барана на откорм.

loans.use: To buy sheep and fodder

loans.name: Mahmadziyo

texts.ru:
Mahmadziyo Karimovich A. is 45 years old, married and has four children. He works as a teacher in the school number 12 in the Baht village and receives a salary of around 200 somoni a month (around US$60). His income was not enough for his family's living expenses so Mahmadziyo had to find another source of income. After he received a loan from MicroInvest his income has grown and he started an entrepreneurship. He opened a trade shop near his house. He receives a stable profit from sales of around US$100 a month.

Mahmadziyo has been in the cattle breeding business for the past 15 years. His family has been helping him. He plans to use the loan to buy a cow. He wants to process the milk and then sell the product in his trade shop.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Vounteer.

Ахмедов Махмадзиё Каримович - 45 лет. Женат имеет четыре детей . Работает учителем в средней школе № 12 поселка Бахт, получает заработную плату около 200 сомони в месяц. Этого не хватает на нужды семьи и он был вынужден искать источник дохода. После получения кредита с МЗФ «Микринвест» его доход увеличился и он начал заниматься предпринимательской деятельностью. Открыл торговую точку возле своего дома .От торговли получает стабильную прибыль около 100$ в месяц.

Откормом скота занимается более 15 лет. Ему помогают жена и дети. На получаемый кредит хочет купить корову. Хочет молоко переработать и полученный продукт продавать на своем магазинчике.

loans.use: To buy a cow for making and selling milk and buttermilk in his trade shop.

loans.name: Hour

texts.en: Mrs. Hour C., 39, is a garment worker. On average, she earns $2 a day of profit. Her husband, who is a logger, makes approximately  $3 a day of profit. This couple has three children, one of who is a logger as his father and earns around $2 a day. The other two children are students. To reduce expenses,  this family requests a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. This will allow the family to save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Thon

texts.en: Mrs. Thon Y., 48, owns a plot of farmland and with her husband works as farmer earning around $2 a day. They have five children, three of whom are married and live away from home. Two others are students. To make the crops grow faster they need to use fertilizers and good rice seed. So now this couple is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase the fertilizer and seed. The remaining money will be used to buy a motorbike to use as a motor-taxi to generate a extra income to support the family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, good rice seed and a motorbike.

loans.name: Sairam

texts.en:
Sairam V.. age 24, and her brother, who is her business partner, have been selling children clothes for seven years in the big market in Dushanbe. Sairam brings goods from Bishkek and her brother sells them in the market. (Unfortunally,she was in Bishkek when we took the photo, so the photo shows her brother with their credit expert, Nargiza, at their trading place ).

Sairam said that she has constant clients in the wholesale market, to whom she also sells her goods. Often, they pay her in advance and she purchases according their orders. They trust her because, in spite of her age, she is a very clever dealer, and she can choose goods that generate demand among her customers. Her brother says that, from childhood, she was clever baby, and always she could find solutions to problems by herself.

Today, Sairam and her brother want to request a Kiva loan to buy new modern shoes and clothes for spring season.

loans.use: Purchase of spring clothes.

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40427

loans.name: Rahim Shah

texts.en: Rahim Shah lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married, and has good experience running a shoe shop. He and his father have run the shop for 15 years in this area, and now Shah will take over the place on his own. He would like to expand the business, so he is requesting an individual loan to import more well-designed shoes to attract more young clients. This will enable him to make a good income. He will be pleased to receive this loan.

loans.use: To import more well-designed shoes

loans.name: Umidajon

texts.en:
N. Umidajon lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 3 children. Mrs. Umidajon has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007, and she has significantly improved her business and opened a store that sells children's clothing and shoes. She has 7 years of experience in the business and has the appropriate skills. She has suppliers and she sells for prices that are lower than the bazaar prices.

Mrs. Umidajon is applying to KIVA for a business development loan of 1200 STJ for 8 months to buy new seasonal wear and to expand her existing assortment of goods.

loans.use: To buy new seasonal clothing and to expand her existing assortment of goods

loans.name: Munira's Group

texts.en:
I am Munira M. and a mother of two: one girl and one boy. Both my kids attend a nearby local school. My husband is a welder and works at a local factory; along with this job, he also runs a small welding store. I mostly do my household chores, but whenever I get free time, I embroider clothes to order for various clients. We are borrowing for the first time and need this loan to expand our welding store. Once our business is established, my husband will longer have to work at the factory.

My group members are: Suriya K., who is borrowing to buy a cow; Sharifan B., who wants to expand their milk shop; and Irshad B., who will buy a donkey cart with her share of the loan.

loans.use: Expand welding business

loans.name: Adigozal

texts.en: Adigozal was born in 1976. He is single, and is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Kalbadjar region, and settled in the Absheron region. Two years ago he started this business. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy clothes to improve his business and grow profits.

loans.use: to buy clothes for his business

loans.name: Sayaad Agha

texts.en: Sayaad Agha lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married, has 3 children, and provides the only income for his family. He has a gas shop, and has been involved in this business for more than two years now. He wants to take out an individual loan to enlarge his shop by purchasing the necessary materials to make a good business. In the future, he would like to help his family more, as his family makes him happy.

loans.use: To increase his shop's supplies

loans.name: Gulomjon

texts.en:
R. Gulomjon was born in 1985 in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. Now, he is a businessman who sells men's clothing and shoes.

He first applied to MicroInvest in 2004, when he heard about their successful business history from his brother. He applied to MicroInvest so that he could structure the business terms to bring him a permanent business income. He has a good assortment of clothing and many repeat customers.

Mr. R. Gulomjon has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 2800 STJ for 6 months to expand his store.

loans.use: To expand his store

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40433

loans.name: Nofal

texts.en: Nofal was born in 1974. He is married, and has 2 children. Nofal is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Kalbadjar region, settled in Absheron region. He has been in this business for 2 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts for his taxi.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his taxi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Mrs. Tep N., 43, is a mother of two children and, with her husband, works selling firewood from their house. They normally earn around $5.50 a day of income. One child  works as a motor-taxi driver, making on average $2 a day of profit and the other is employed by a garment factory and earns a salary $60 a month. To raise the family's standard of living, the husband requests a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike to run as a motor-taxi to produce additional income. Mrs. Tep N. can manage the firewood selling business without her husband. (Mrs. Tep N. and her husband were not available for the picture so her son is pictured with the motorbike they hope to purchase).

loans.use: To purchase a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Shoira

texts.en:
K. Shoira has been a client of MicroInvest since 2004. She considers herself to be a serious and business-like client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure.

Mrs. K. Shoira sells men's clothing and shoes. She works with the direct suppliers, so she trades at prime cost and has many repeat customers. Mrs. K. Shoira has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 2500 STJ for 8 months to develop her business by importing new seasonal goods.

loans.use: To buy new seasonal goods

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
I am Nasreen Y.. I have been married for 20 years and have four kids: two girls and two boys, all of whom are in school except for my eldest daughter. I send them school so that they can prosper in their lives and can earn a decent living for themselves. My husband and I both work on a brick furnace. I also raise cows at home. With the current loan I plan to renovate my semi-brick house.

I am joined in my group by few other women: Zahida B., whose husband is a public transport driver; Shahnaz M., whose husband buys and sells bricks; and Suriya B., who is borrowing for her family’s grocery store. All of these women are my friends and want to improve their economic conditions.

loans.use: Renovate current brick mud house

loans.name: Emy

texts.en:
Emy is 28 years old and is a single woman. She takes care of two other people, ages 18 and 15. Emy is a clothes seller; she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Easther

texts.en:
Easther is 27 years old and is a single woman. Easther owns a small salon, which she started in 2008. Every day, she works from 8 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $240 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
My name is Shahnaz M.. I am married and a mother of eight. I live with my family in a small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. Four of my kids attend school while four others do not. My husband works at a government organization while I raise goats at home. When these goats reach a reasonable age I sell them for decent profits. I would like to buy a few more goats.

I would like to borrow along with a group of other women: Batool H., who needs this loan to expand her agriculture business; Zahida B., who also raises crops; Sakina B., who will use the loan to improve their embroidery business; and Rubina B., who will buy a dairy cow with her share of the loan.

loans.use: Buy a few more goats

loans.name: Sanavbar

texts.en:
R. Sanavbar lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is not married but she has a child. Despite the fact that she is a single mother, she is full of enthusiasm and ready to work hard to ensure a happy future for her child.

Mrs. Sanavbar sells men's clothing. She has 10 years of experience in the business and she dreams of having a large-scale business. She has a good assortment of clothing.

Mrs. Sanavbar has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 1800 STJ for 8 months to import new seasonal goods.

loans.use: To import new seasonal clothing

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 28 years old and is a single woman. Grace owns a small shop, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 9 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more commodities for her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business

loans.name: Gulara

texts.en: Gulara is a mother of one child. She was born in 1986. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli region, settled in Absheron region. She has run this business for 4 years. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy the more food for her store, and grow her profits.

loans.use: to buy more food for her general store

loans.name: Oibeck

texts.en:
R. Oibeck was born in 1981 in the J.Rasulova region of Tajikistan. He is married and has a child. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007, and he considers himself to be a serious and business-like client.

Mr. R. Oibeck is a schoolteacher by profession, but his primary family income comes from livestock farming. It is the family business that was started by his father. Mr. R. Oibeck raises and sells livestock. He has a large flock and he is experienced in this sphere of the business.

Mr. R. Oibeck has applied to KIVA for a loan of 2500 STJ to build a barn for his cows, which will allow him to increase the size of his herd.

loans.use: To build a barn for his cows

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran B. has three kids: two girls and one boy. Her eldest daughter is married; her son is in ninth grade and her youngest daughter is in sixth grade. Her husband is a public transport driver and Sughran runs a milk shop from her house, selling milk and yogurt. She started this shop few years ago after her husband was in an accident. After the accident, her husband could not work for five years and Sughran was the only bread winner for the family. Fortunately her husband is able to work again.

Sughran's group members are: Walan Z., who needs to buy a cow; Basheeran A., a widow whose son runs a grocery store and milk shop; and Safia B., who is also widow and runs a dairy business.

loans.use: Expand milk shop

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.en:
R. Nargiza lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006 and she has proven to be a reliable client. The stability of her business has helped her to repay her previous loans on time, and to improve the business terms significantly.

Mrs. Nargiza sells children's clothing and she has a good assortment. She has applied to KIVA for the loan of 1600 STJ to open a new trade outlet that will permit her to increase and expand her existing assortment of clothing.

loans.use: To open a new store

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 29 years old and is divorced with 2 children, ages 10 months and 9 years old. Fatuma is a clothes seller; she started in 2002. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Mariam A. S. is from a small lush green town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is married with seven kids: one boy and six girls. All of her kids are studying at local schools. It is her great desire and passion that all her kids finish their schooling and can become successful. Her husband is an auto mechanic and runs a small auto spare parts shop.

Mariam is a group leader of few other women, who are her neighbors and fellow entrepreneurs: Zubaida M. is borrowing for their motorcycle rental, Shamim B.’s husband runs a furniture store, Seema B. will invest her loan to fix her husband’s taxi, and Sughran Sadiq wants to buy a cow.

This is a group loan and the funds will be distributed among all group members.

loans.use: Expand spare parts shop

loans.name: Tukae

texts.en:
Tukae is 31 years old and a married woman. Tukae owns a small pharmacy, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7AM to 6 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $23 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her pharmacy

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
I, Bushra B., am a mother of four kids: three boys and one girl. My husband died few years ago and we faced a great economic crises. My elder sons dropped out of school and took the responsibility to earn an income. I have a piece of a harvest land where I grow wheat and rice. One of my sons raises cows and sells milk; currently he needs to buy an additional cow. I save a small sum out of my earnings on monthly basis for my kids' future.

My fellow group members are: Sughran T., who also wants to buy a cow; Hajra B., who will buy a saw machine with her share of loan; and Sajida B., who is a partner in her brother’s cloth shop.

loans.use: Buy an additional cow

loans.name: Tukae

texts.en:
Tukae is 31 years old and is married woman. Tukae owns a small pharmacy, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $23 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her pharmacy

loans.name: Djahid

texts.en: Djahid (his brother is pictured ) is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town. He is settled in the Fizuli region, Bala Bahmanli village. He has 5 years of experience in this business.  Now this 30-year-old man needs a loan of $1200 to buy more clothes to meet customer demand.

loans.use: To buy clothes for the business

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen B. is a group leader for three other entrepreneur women, all of whom are very hard-working and play an important role in getting income for their families. Nasreen will use her portion of the loan to improve and expand her jewelry business.

The group also includes Koser B., who raises livestock; Parween S., whose husband runs a tea stall; and Sughran B., who also has a dairy business.

This is a group loan, and the group members are mutually responsible for paying back the entire loan.

loans.use: Expand jewelry and other businesses

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a married woman with one 5-year-old child. She and her husband also take care of two other people, aged 25. Veronica is a clothes seller; she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8 AM to 4 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Veronica has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma is married with three children, ages 13, 3, and 1. Rahma is a clothing vendor and started her business in 2007. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $80.

Rahma is applying for a loan of $175 to buy more clothing for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for resale

loans.name: Khakima

texts.en:
T. Khakima is 31 years old. She is married and has two children. She lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan, where she trades by the perfumery and the women wear. Mrs. T. Khakima started practically from scratch, but thanks to the returns from her MicroInvest loans, she has improved her business and opened her own store. She has a wide assortment of goods. She trades by the different sorts of the women wear.

Mrs. T. Khakima has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 8 months to expand her store and buy a new assortment of goods.

loans.use: To expand her store and buy a new assortment of goods

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business #40456

loans.name: Narimanov

texts.ru:
T. Narimanov is 41 years old and has two children. His wife is a housewife. T. works as a freelance constructor and also feeds and breeds cattle besides his main source of income. His wife is helping him with this business. Currently, he has one cow and ten goats. His wife also spins yarn from the goat fur from which she has income by selling wholesale at the Chairuhskiy market. T. has turned to MicroInvest to increase the number of heads of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Vounteer.

Нариманов Туйчи возрост 41 год имеет 2 детей жена домохозяйка.Туйчи работает строителем на заказ , По мимо своего осноаного дохода Туйчи занимается откормом скота.Ему помогает жена по уходу за скотом.На данный момент он имеет 1 корову и 10 коз. Также его жена прядет прядь из козьей шерсти, с чего также имеет доход, продавая оптом на Чайрухском базаре.Для увеличения численности скота Туйчи обратился в Микроинвест.

loans.use: To increase number of cattle

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40457

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.en:
Bahodur is 27 years old. He is married and has two children. His business is located at his house. He has a wide yard where he keeps his goods.

His business is to sell carpet of different sizes (1x1.5, 2x2.5, and 3x4). He has been engaged in this business for over 3 years. His two brothers are his business partners. They have families and live with him. They buy their goods from local workshops and they also bring carpets from Kairakkum, Tajikistan. In the photo, you can see that they have a wide assortment of carpets. (Bahodur is on the left, and his credit expert, Unusov, is on the right). It is their family business and they are a large and very friendly family. Two of his brothers sell carpets at the market and he sells his goods at home. They have many constant clients from further regions. Today they have fast turnover of their working capital.

They wish to participate In KIVA to increase the number of their carpets so they can attract new clients.

loans.use: Purchase new types of carpets

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 28 years old and is single with two children, ages 10 and 7. Amina sells cloth, a business she started in 2005. She works every day from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. earns a monthly profit of about $140.

Amina is applying for a loan of $150 to buy more cloth for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business

loans.name: Zamir

texts.en: Zamir was born in 1976, and is single. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town,  settled in Fuzuli region Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. He has sold engine oil for 5 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy machine oil to improve his business and try to make more profits.

loans.use: To buy machine oil

loans.name: Javlon

texts.en:
S. Javlon is 23 years old and he is married. He lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan and is in the livestock business. He also works with a building team, doing finishing and repair work on apartments, but his general family income comes from the family business of raising and selling livestock. His wife has a dairy business.

Mr. S. Javlon has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ for 8 months to buy a pedigreed bull.

loans.use: To buy a pedigreed bull

loans.name: Kidawa

texts.en:
Kidawa is 28 years old and is married with two children, ages 7 and 1 1/2. She and her husband also take care of two other adults. Kidawa owns a small shop, which she opened in 2007. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $140.

Kidawa now hopes for a loan of $175 to buy more goods for resale in her store.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of her general store

loans.name: Kurbonjon

texts.en:
E. Kurbonjon was born in 1972 in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan and she is married. Mrs. E. Kurbonjon has been a client of MicroInvest since 2002, and she is an active and responsible client. She is engaged in the family livestock business. She helped her husband take care of the livestock and milk production. On the side, she is engaged in the commercial service and trade of sweets. She has a good assortment.

Mrs. E. Kurbonjon has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 8 months to purchase supplies, such as sugar, sweets, and cakes, to expand her assortment of sweets and better face the stiff competition in her business sector.

loans.use: To expand her assortment of sweets

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business #40463

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 25 years old. He is married and has one child. He is living with his parents in a rented house. His father and mother are elderly. He has an old taxi and he wants to borrow $1200 to replace this car with a new one in order to increase his income. He wants to save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Replace the old car with a new one

loans.name: Hosiyat

texts.en:
Hosiyat is a very strong business woman. She is wholesaler of household goods, which she buys in lots and sells to several trade places at different markets.She is 57 years old and she is an energetic women with a great potential for work. Her two sons help her to import and export goods from market to their stockhouse, where clients come to purchase goods and place orders for future goods.

Hosiyat has been engaged in this kind of business for over 10 years and has many constant clients. In the photo, you can see Hosiyat on the left and her credit expert, Toirov K, on the right. She is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase the next batch of goods.

loans.use: To buy products for her household goods business

loans.name: Maria's Starehe Group

texts.en:
Maria is 34 years old and is married with two children, ages 16 and 12 years old. Maria owns a small food store, which she started in 2004. She works every day from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $60.

She now hopes for a loan of $350 to buy more food items for her store. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mwajuma, who has a business in clothing sales.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Fatuma's Starehe Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 26 years old and married with two children, ages 12 and 8. Fatuma owns a small food store, which she opened in 2006. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $90.

Fatuma would like a loan of $650 to replenish her stock of foodstuffs. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in clothing sales, food vending, and a beauty salon.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her food store

loans.name: Anorjon

texts.en:
B. Anorjon has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2003. She is a very reliable and responsible client. The stability of her business helped her to repay her previous loans on time and to improve her business, so she opened a store that sells material and curtains. She has a very good assortment and many repeat customers because she sells at prices that are lower than the bazaar prices.

Mrs. B. Anorjon has applied to KIVA for a loan of 2100 STJ for 6 months to buy new goods for her business.

loans.use: To buy new goods for her curtain store

loans.name: Shani's Starehe Group

texts.en:
Shani M. is 36 years old and married with two children, ages 7 and 1 1/2. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 46 and 19. Shani sells clothing, a business she started in 2006. She works every day from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $110.

Shani is applying for a loan of $350 to buy more cloth for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Regina, who is a food vendor.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for her business

loans.name: Kaundime

texts.en:
Kaundime is divorced with a 5-year-old child. She owns a small clothing shop, which she opened in 2007. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $140.

Kaundime is applying for a loan of $175 to buy more clothing items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Zikamoh

texts.en:
Zikamoh has demonstrated that she is a responsible and accurate client of our organization. She is married and has 3 children. She lives with her parents-in-law and helps her husband to support their family. Her business is the selling of fruit, such as oranges, apples, and pears.

Early in the morning, at 5:00 a.m, she goes to the food market and buys fruit from the peasants. Every day she buys goods for 200 TJ somoni (~ $58 USD) and earns a profit of 40-50 TJ somoni (~$12-$15 USD). She spends all of her profits on family needs.

When she heard about the KIVA program, she wanted to receive a loan to increase her working capital. She plans to involve her elder son in her business, renting a trading place for him, and buying fruit for him to sell. In the photo, she is the second person from the left.

loans.use: Purchase the next batch of fruits and rent one more trading place.

loans.name: Mwanaharusi's Liwiti Group

texts.en:
Mwanaharusi Liwiti is 44 years old and married with five children, ranging in age from 24 to 12 years old. She and her husband also support two other adults. Mwanaharusi sells clothing, a business she started in 2006. She works every day from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan of $1050 to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in clothing sales, a beauty salon, charcoal sales, and tailoring.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of clothing for sale in her business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose M. is 37 years old and married with four children, ranging in age from 13 years to 4 months. Rose owns a small grocery and sells chips, which she started in 2007. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $70.

Rose would like a loan of $150 to to increase the variety of items for sale in her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her grocery store

loans.name: Euris Josefina

texts.en:
Euris Josefina is an active businesswoman that lives in the Zapotal community of Nizao. She is 32 years old and has four children that range in age from 8 to 17 years old. Euris sells women’s clothing and underwear, and has been running this business for more than one year.

The entrepreneur is requesting a loan to expand and improve her business. Specifically, she would like to purchase a new collection of chic underwear and stylish clothing. Euris hopes that her business’ success will generate enough revenue to allow her to visit another country someday and to continue to provide for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing in bulk in order to restock her small store.

loans.name: Nyamizi

texts.en:
Nyamizi K. is married with two children, ages 3 1/2 and 2 years. Nyamizi owns a small beauty salon, which she opened in 2005. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her clients.

Nyamizi is applying for a loan of $175 to buy more supplies for her business.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her beauty salon

loans.name: Abdusamad

texts.en:
From childhood, Abdusamad watched the process of making Tajik cradles ("govra") and learned the craft from his father and grandfather. It has been their family business for long time. Abdusamad has two brothers and one sister, and with their mother and father, they help to make govra.

The process consists of several steps; first cutting the details of the govra, soaking them in water for one to two days (for flexibility and for shape), fashioning the details, and then assembling the pieces into govra and fastening them with tacks. The final step is painting a design on the cradle.

Today, his business is going well and he has many clients that have purchased his govra for many years. Abdusamad loves his work and does it with great pleasure, but now he needs a loan to buy wood and tools for his business. He plans to open a workshop and employ several assistants, because he gets more orders from different regions of Tajikistan. In the photo, Abdusamad is in the middle near his govra, with our credit expert, who is holding documents in his hand.

loans.use: To buy wood and tools for making cradles ("govra")

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase raw materials in bulk to produce ice cream and mabí.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional clothing and jewelry in bulk for her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To rent space and to purchase raw materials to produce food for a small business.

loans.name: Kayembe's Ujira Mwema Group

texts.en:
Kayembe is 35 years old and married with one 10-yr.-old child. She and her husband also take care of another person, age 58. Kayembe owns a small food store, which she opened in 2005. She works every day from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Kayembe would like a loan of $275 to increase the inventory of her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member July , who also has a food vending business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her grocery store

loans.name: Hilda María

texts.en:
Hilda María is 40 years old and is the mother of five children between the ages of 14 and 25 years old, all of whom attend school. Hilda María sells fruits and vegetables, and she proudly claims that her products are sold as quickly as she can stock them. She also sells peanuts, boiled beans, sugar, and other such goods that people in her community need on a daily basis.

Hilda María plans to use this loan to expand her business by adding new kinds of fruits and vegetables. With the loan, she would also like to rent a small local where she can easily run her business. In short, the loan would allow the entrepreneur to increase her sales volume and revenue and, as a result, she will be able to improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To acquire fruits, vegetables, and other food products, and to rent space for her small business.

loans.name: Hidaya's Sharoom. Group

texts.en:
Hidaya N. is 25 years old and single. She owns a small food store, which she opened in 2006. She works every day from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $60.

Hidaya would like a loan of $275 to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a food vending business.

loans.use: To buy mora food items for her grocery store

loans.name: Roxanna

texts.en:
Roxanna is 26 years old and is a single mother of her 6-year-old son. Roxanna owns and operates a nail care center in the Zapotal community of Nizao. At the nail care center, she offers services in acrylic polish changes, American and French manicures and pedicures, etc. However, she also offers private services to customers who are too busy to go to her salon.

Roxanna plans to use this loan to buy materials such as nail varnish, artificial nails, files, and a special table for the business. She hopes that before long she’ll have enough money to design a comfortable beauty parlor. This way, the entrepreneur will be able to attend to her customers in a pleasant space, and she will in turn improve her family’s living conditions because her business will generate additional income.

loans.use: To acquire materials and products for a nail care center.

loans.name: Wanyama West C (Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty I.. She is currently in the business of running a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell. Betty is 49 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from ages 23 to 29. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 12000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for the household necessities. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Hadijah T. and Resty Nabiry. Hadijah T. has a business selling charcoal and wants to add more stock. Resty N. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge and more items.

loans.use: To add to drug shop business

loans.name: Aury Esther

texts.en:
Aury Esther is 28 years old and is the proud mother of a 9-year-old daughter and an 11-year-old son, both of whom attend school. Aury recently finished secondary school and she plans to start her university studies shortly. Aury has been running an open-air, barbecue restaurant for more than three years in the Media Blanca community of Nizao. Each day, many people visit her restaurant to enjoy the great variety of delicious food she offers. Aury explains that with profits from her business, she has purchased furniture for her living room and is able to pay for her children’s education.

The entrepreneur says that she would like to have a bigger restaurant with many employees and even more customers who will come to her restaurant every day to buy her great food. She is seeking a loan to buy a large quantity of raw materials to cook her menu items. Holy Week is a great opportunity for Aury to increase her sales volume because people love to enjoy barbecue food during this holiday.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to improve and expand her open-air, barbecue restaurant.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is 54 years old and is married with five grown children. Juliana owns a small food store, which she opened in 2000. She works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $15 from her sales.
She would like a loan of $150 to buy more food items to stock in her store.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her small grocery store

loans.name: Rosa Emilia

texts.en:
Rosa Emilia is 43 years old and is a single mother of four girls between the ages of 10 and 18 years old, all of whom attend school. Rosa sells men’s and children’s clothing in the Media Blanca community of Nizao. She also produces homeM. “mabí”, a non-alcoholic beverage that is said to lower blood pressure and cholesterol and to make the men more potent. Naturally, this drink is always in high demand, so Rosa has to constantly purchase more and more raw materials to make the drink to satisfy her customers.

Rosa Emilia hopes that her business’s continued growth will enable her to complete her house, which is under construction. With this loan, Rosa Emilia would like to purchase clothing in bulk and additional raw materials to keep producing her magic drink.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to produce mabí and to purchase clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Mary's Tujiendeleze Group

texts.en:
Mary is 29 years old and is married with three children, ages 13, 9, and 3 1/2 years old. Mary sells vegetables, a business she started in 2005. She works every day from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Mary would like a loan of $400 to buy more vegetable for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mwanahamisi and Mwajuma, who also have businesses in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her produce business

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes was born and raised in Media Blanca, a small community of the Nizao municipality where African roots, beliefs, and culture are very strong. Women in Media Blanca are very active and hard-working, and they carry on various kinds of businesses in order to earn a living. Mercedes has been influenced by these women and has decided to follow in their footsteps.

Therefore, she owns and operates a small store which helps to pay for her education costs and to support her unique 1-year-old son. Mercedes’ store offers a collection of a la mode eau de cologne, clothing, jewelry, and cosmetics. She started her business one year ago with a loan from FSMA. Currently, her business is well-established in the community and she has many loyal customers.

The entrepreneur is seeking a loan to increase her inventory, especially the beauty products, which will enable Mercedes to continue to satisfy her customers’ needs and will thereby increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics, jewelry, and clothing for her small business.

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en: Gulsara is 48 years old. She is a divorced mother of 2 children. She has her own food shop and her main business is trading jewelry that she buys from suppliers in Turkey. She has two sellers, one at her shop, and one for jewelry. (In the photo she is the second from the right.) She gets good monthly profits from her business and her assets are increasing. She has a good turnover of her working capital and she wants to receive a loan to increase the volume of her goods.

loans.use: To expand her jewelry business

loans.name: Wanyama West B (I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Zaina M.. She is currently in the business of running a grocery shop and is requesting a loan to buy more items. Zaina is 35 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver for work. She has 5 children ranging from ages 7 to 17 and her children go to school. Each week, Zaina makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her household's necessities. Zaina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to open up a kiosk and the loan was paid back on time.

Zaina is joined in her small group by Milly N. and Harriet B.. Milly N. has a business selling matooke and wants to increase her purchases. Harriet B. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase more shop items.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and add to her shop

loans.name: Chausiku's Tujitegemee. Group

texts.en:
Chausiku is 35 years old and is married with three children, ages 15, 7 and 3. She and her husband also take care of one person, who is 55 years old. Chausiku owns a small cafe, which she opened in 2004. She works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $280 from cafe sales.

She would like a loan of $275 to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mariam, who also works in the cafe.

loans.use: To buy more items for her cafe business

loans.name: Wanyama West B (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ruth N.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Ruth is 30 years old and is divorced. Each week, Ruth makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her family's needs. Ruth has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Ruth is joined in her small group by Samuel N. and Francis N.. Samuel N. has a business running a grocery shop and wants to open up a small retail shop. Francis N. is currently operating a business selling water and tailoring and wants a loan to purchase more fabric.

loans.use: To add more capital to charcoal business

loans.name: Zamda

texts.en:
Zamda is 48 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 30, 29, 18, and 12 years old. Zamda owns a small food store, which she started in 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Wanyama West B (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty Nkimbugwe. She is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to put up a boutique. Betty is 25 years old and is married. Her husband is a hairdresser. She has 2 children aged 3 and 5, and both of her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save and add to her clothes business. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy more clothes and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Margret A., Faith N. and Agnes N.. Margret A. has a business running a grocery and wants to purchase more groceries. Faith N. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to stock more charcoal. Agnes N. operates a retail shop business and wants to purchase more shop items.

loans.use: To add to clothing sales business

loans.name: Abdurahimov

texts.ru:
A. Abdurahimov has finished high school and is now a businessman. He is not married yet. Besides his main business of selling small miscellaneous merchandise and groceries he is also in the animal husbandry business. He is the oldest son in his family and that's why he is responsible for his family's living expenses. His mother is a housewife. A. consults his father when buying and selecting cattle. His father is a good veterinarian and has knowledge about cattle.

A. thinks that it's better to get a loan to buy new cattle for his business rather than spend his profits. Currently, he owns two cows and eight sheep.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдурахимов Абдубурхон парень закончивший среднюю школу и занимающийся бизнесом. Пока не женат помимо своего бизнеса по продаже мелочного товара , продуктов питания он занимается откормом скота и его продажей. В семье он старший сын и на его шее все расходы на жизнь.Мать домохозяйка, а Абдубурхон советуется по выбору скота сосвоим отцом.Его отец хороший ветеринар и хорошо разбирается в скоте.

Абдубурхон считает что чем уменьшить активы своего бизнеса для приобретения мелкорогатого скота, ему лучше взять в Микроинвесте кредит.На сегодня он имеет 2 коровы и 8 баранов.

loans.use: To buy cattle

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 40496

loans.name: Neema's Mkombozi Group

texts.en:
Neema A. is a 24-year-old married mother of one living in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. To help support her five-year-old child, she sells cloth from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day. Her hard work earns her family about $60 a month.

Neema hopes to expand her business, which is why she has applied for a group loan of $1,125 U.S. dollars. Her loan partners, Asha A. and Ashura I., have their own businesses selling cloth and charcoal. Neema has taken out two successful loans in the past, so she is confident that they will be able to repay this loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more cloth items for her business.

loans.name: Mirzo

texts.ru:
Mirzo Sobirovich A. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is 43 years old, married and has six children. He has secondary education and is in the retail business. He has own vendor point on the market where he sells spare parts. He brings in the merchandise from Dushanbe (capital of Tajikistan) which he buys from wholesalers. He has been in this business for the past five years. Mirzo wants to increase the variety of his merchandise and also increase sales by getting a loan. This will help him increase his profits and also supply the markets with necessary spare parts for the locals residents. He plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Азизов Мирзо Собирович проживает в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Возраст 43 года, женат , имеет 6 детей.Образование среднее . Занимается бизнесом в сфере торговли . Имеет торговую точку на рынке.Торгует запчастями. Завозит товар из города Душанбе ,приобретая у оптовых реализаторов. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 5 лет. Хочет увеличить ассортимент товара , а так же увеличить товарооборот , путем получения кредита.Это поможет клиенту увеличить доходность , а так же обеспечить рынки необходимыми запачастями, не выезжая для этого в город. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Ebenezer

texts.en:
Ebenezer is the person sitting on the far right, and the others are members of his staff. Ebenezer is 35 years old, married, and the father of 4 children, 3 of whom are enrolled in school. He has been working in the sewing business for over 5 years. He specializes in the creation of pants and shirts. Ebenezer’s shop is located in a small village called Avetonou, about 120 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. Therefore, he travels to the capital to acquire the fabrics with which he creates his clothing. Ebenezer desires to use his loan to acquire 2 more sewing machines to increase his business activity so that he can continue to meet the needs of his family and participate in the development of his community.

Ebenezer est la personne située à l’extrème droit et les autres personnes sont ses collaboreurs. Ebenezer est agé de 35 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants dont 3 sont sur les bancs de l’école. Il opère dans la couture depuis plus de 5 ans. Il est specialisé dans la création de pantalons et de chemises. L’atelier d’Ebenezer est situé à Avetonou, un petit village situé à environ 120 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Donc, il va souvent à Lomé pour acquerir les tissus à partir desquels il confectionne ses vêtements. Ebenezer désire avec les fonds dont il bénéficiera acquérir 2 machines à coudre pour améliorer son activité afin de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille et participer ainsi au développement de sa communauté.

loans.use: To buy 2 sewing machines

loans.name: Shani's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Shani M. is a 27-year-old married woman living in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. To help support her two children, ages 3 and 7, Shani works from 6:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day selling spare parts. Her hard work earns her family about $70 a month in profits.

Shani hopes to grow her business, which is why she's applied for a group loan of $450 U.S dollars. She completely trusts her two loan partners, Ashura A. and Mariam A.. Both of these women also wish to expand their own businesses, selling fish and other food.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for a small parts business

loans.name: Budumbuli West A (I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Juliet N.. She is currently in the business of selling firewood and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of firewood. Juliet is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a builder for work. She has 2 children aged 4 and 6, and her children go to school. Each week, Juliet makes approximately UGX 450000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her household necessities. Juliet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.
